review_body: Stayed here for one week. I was very impressed by the polite, helpful and friendly staff. The beds are very Comfortable. Very good location for the station and the many restaurants. Ginza is a very safe and prosperous area. Great breakfast.

I had put the Do Not Disturb sign on my door for most of my stay but decided that I needed extra amenities on the second last night of my stay. My sis left her watch on the table but came back to find it missing. We thought it was a mistake given the great reviews for this hotel so we raised it to the hotel and the hotel reassured us that they will check with their cleaning staff. They did not get back to us until we asked about it when we were checking out. To which they simple told us that the item was not seen and could not be found.Unfortunately, as we were rushing to catch our flight, we left behind an iPad Pro in the room which we were using just that morning. On the direct train to the domestic airport, we realised that it was left behind (only an hour has passed) and called up the hotel, hoping that they would keep the iPad until we returned to Tokyo a couple of days later. But the hotel informed us that the room has been cleaned and there was no iPad to be found. There was no way that the iPad was left anywhere else and we clearly remembered that we left it in the room. Such a dishonest hotel should be avoid at all costs. What an expensive lesson to be learnt. Perhaps Tokyu stay next door would be a better option.

I love its location and its bath room. Room space is not enough to unfold two large pieces of luggage. It took us only 2 minutes to walk to the subway Higash-Ginza station, so as to walk to the main street of Ginza.

Located in heart of Ginza area, onlymin from department, restaurant and Donquihote. easy to access to anywhere in Tokyo by subway and JR. Only 40 mins to Disney resort. Hotel is great enough for traveller with reasonable price.

Stayed for 4 nights with parents in standard double room. Size is good by Tokyo standard (200 sq meters+). Good condition - seems quite new. Very clean and tidy. Close to metro station (2-3 min walk), shopping, food (many options around). Front desk staffs v helpful. WiFi works fine. Very happy with my choice and will stay here again in future.

Excellent hotel, in great location in Ginza district. Staff was very helpful. Room was on the larger side (compared to another hotel we stayed at for one night at beginning of trip. Lots of nice toiletry items in the bathroom. We didn't eat at the hotel, but there were several restaurants close by. Hotel staff recommended the Starbucks Reserve right around the corner for a quick easy breakfast. This is the place to go if you are a coffee snob. It's a step above the regular starbucks.

My trip was cancel due to the Typoon Kammuri. The Management was kind enough and did not charge me anything for not arriving in time although they could have. That was a very nice gesture from their part. Thank you verymuch

I was very excited to be back in Tokyo after 5 years, waited far too long but oh dear oh dear where to stay? Options are limitless but rooms are really small and super expensive, especially closer to the Centre. Ginza is the main hub and in the middle of everything as far as I’m concerned and it was important for me to stay in or near Ginza. Therefore this little gem of a hotel was just perfect. Very central, decent size room, great service as you would expect and immaculate amenities, just perfect for a business or leisure trip and all under $250, total bargain. I can highly recommend it and will stay again. Watch out breakfast can get packed and you might have to que if you go at 8am so leave plenty of time if you rushing off to a meeting. Such a great little hotel and loved the power shower !!!

The hotel is not as good as its Kyoto counterpart however it is still large enough rooms, clean and centrally located. I would recommend this hotel to anyone wanting to stay in Ginza. The staff were helpful and good little ramen restaurant across the road.

It is a nice hotel with friendly and helpful front desk staffs with English speaking, easy access, just 5 minutes walk to Metro and shops. The room Superior Twin is large enough ( 20 sq.m) for 2 large luggages. The guest room provides free tea, coffee and water, and bathroom amenities.

The hotel is located in the heart of Ginza, very short walk to the main shopping artery, to Ginza Crossing and 2 metro stations. Delicious breakfast. The room was small, but extra clean and comfortable. The bathroom has a whole range of wonderful toiletries. Highly recommended!

Although the hotel rooms are a little small, the space is adequate and the facilities are efficient for business travel. The hotel is clean and location is convenient, right next to nishi ginza underground (hibiya line) and a few minutes walk to ginza station. There are no smoking rooms/ areas so if you are not a smoker great news, if you are, you have to leave the hotel area to smoke. The windows can open slightly which i find is always a plus to let in fresh air rather than breathing circulated air from the aircon.Amenities include a daily skincare set by DHC and nice shampoos and body soap.

Excellent staffs,location,very clean room,nice coffee machine,well supplied drinking water and for coffee makerSuperb bath room and nice toiletries.Will always staying at Solaria ginza . The lobby waiting room before check in and check out waiting for the car to airport is very comfortable.

I loved how close the hotel was to restaurants, malls, Family Mart/Lawson for essentials, the train station and most importantly, Tsukiji Market! I will definitely book here again and highly recommend it to friends and family.

My first visit to Tokyo and was recommended this hotel by a friend. A good choice indeed, The location is only one metrostop and abt 500m walk from Tokyo station and airport trains, or 10 min in taxi which I chose because of (too much) luggage.Staff at front desk speaks a decent english and is very helpful trying to cater for your needs and questions. Numerous restaurants and shopping available in the neighborhood, so I did not try the restaurant in hotel except for breakfast, which was nice but a bit different even for the hot choice looking like western :-)Rooms was fully equipped with all amenities - incl free coffee and tea, complimentary WiFi, even a local "Handy" phone to bring around if chosen. Cleanliness and standard of room was in the absolute high end, highly recommendable and definately my choice again........

It was our first time in Tokyo. From Narita airport we took the bus from terminal 2 for 1000yen. Very smooth ride to Ginza stn. Then jumped into a cab for 400 yens.The hotel is centrally located ,easy access to metro, Tushuji fish market,Tokyo stn.Imperial palace etc.etc.Very clean,quet, reasonably priced hotel with helpful staff with llittle english enough to help you.Did not have breakfast in the restaurant.

The hotel has a great location, a few steps away from the metro (direct line to Haneda airport), with lots of shops and restaurants aroundThe reception is well-manned – I never had to wait, even at peak hoursBuilding and rooms look pretty newThe double room is a bit small for two; however, it has most amenities you might want (except a shaving mirror and an iron), including two bottles of water per dayThe bath has a bathtub-cum-shower (with shower curtain, for a change), with a toilet (one of the Japanese ‘super-toilets’) in the same room; I liked the heated mirror, allowing you to use it directly after a showerThe bed was comfortable (better than other business hotels in Japan I slept in), with two pillow types; the curtains do a good job at keeping the daylight out, and it is quiet at night – I slept very wellThe WiFi works well; there also is a free-of-charge mobile phone in the room for your use during your stayBreakfast is a combination of a (limited choice) buffet and a selection of four breakfast menus; I found tasty dishes that suited my preferences (try the Panna Cotta), but am not sure everyone else would The restaurant is ok (nice interior) but expensive; given the multitude of offers in the neighbourhood, it is probably not the best choice, unless you absolutely do not want to go out

Solaria Nishitetsu Hotel was an enjoyable stay. Located in the heart of the Ginza District, the hotel is nicely appointed and very clean. The staff is very attentive and speak English well. Only a 5 minute walk from Ginza Station.

The room was so small we didn’t even have space for our luggage with our kids. The garage could only fit small cars. If you have something slightly larger you have to park elsewhere. The restaurant will only take reservations, you cannot walk in and the run out of reservations pretty quick. I asked for extra pillows and I was told there are no extra pillows in the hotel. Terrible experience, would not recommend at all

Real four stars hotelsExcelent surroundingsExcellent tube connection (several lines less than 5 min)Staff is helpfullPlenty of cafes, restaurants in the areaRooms a little bit smaller than expected, but not a concern

A compact room with all the modern necessities, you really couldn't want more. There is also a free in-room smart phone that you can borrow with unlimited local telephone calls and super handy to use for google maps and finding local things to do in Tokyo. As always, Japanese service is impeccable.

Did tons of reaearch on where to stay in Tokyo-Ginza and this hotel turned out to be excellent decisions. Best Ramen (across the street), shopping and several transit stations right nearby making it super easy to get anywhere. Strong wifi. Room very clean, quiet, more spacious than typical NYC one & well stocked with personal items. Staff english was challenging (not atypical). Wasn’t crazy about the restaurant (overpriced breakfast) but why go all the way to Japan and eat at your hotel anyway. Would definitely stay here again. Tip: they told us to exit Higashi-Ginza station at exit “7” and there literally is no sign for 7. Go to 8 and the hotel is around the corner.

Located in the center of Ginza. It is near Matsuya, Mitsukoshi Dept Store. Room we stay is premier type which can have 3 beds. Hotel aminity is good quality. Nearby, you can find good cafe, good food. Hotel staff is nice and helpful. We can have ippudo ramen, good shabu, good sushi and walk a bit to ginza street.

Right in the heart of Ginza district (think Mayfair, London) and 5mins from the tube and major shopping centres. Some good places to eat nearby. Hotel rooms are small but that's just Japan, everything clean and staff very friendly. Can't comment on restaurant/breakfasts as we didn't eat at the hotel. All in all a nice hotel for exploring Tokyo.

We were told that hotel rooms in Japan are generally smaller than say in Europe or America. This is true. But smaller does not mean less pratical or less comfortable; on the contrary. Thiis is one of the most functional hotel rooms I ever used. From the bathroom to the writing desk, everything uses a minimum of space for a maximum in pratical use. When you stay there you do not need any toiletry; everything (and I mean everything) is here. The yukata at disposal is a tad small, as Japanese are generally smaller then caucausians. The breakfast came as a choice of 4 and was very good indeed,

We were happy with this hotel except for the size of the double room. One side of the bed is against the wall of the bathroom. Consequently, my husband who nicely took that side had to scooch down to the end of the bed to get out of it. That room is adequate for a single traveler but not two. The hotel provides a smartphone, of which we made good use. The hotel restaurant offers Italian fare in the evening. The same restaurant serves breakfast, which we always passed on for an opportunity to enjoy more Japanese food. The bed was on the firm side but comfortable. The pillows were too.We took the subway from the airport; make sure you don't take the express. The hotel is an easy walk from the Ginza station. You're right in the Ginza shopping district as well. The hotel is also about an 8-min walk to Tsukiji Market. I'm not a fast walker. We would stay at the hotel again but opt for a bigger room next time.

My girlfriends and I stayed here for a vacation in Tokyo. The location is superb because when you shop for a lot of things around Ginza, you can just walk back to Solaria to drop off your shopping bags then shop again. The subway exit nearest to it is the Matsuya Ginza exit. Rooms are clean and their toilets have very helpful amenities and beauty products for women.

Because we enjoyed our stay at the Solaria Nishtestsu Ginza in April, 2018 we decided to go back again this March 2019. Like last year, we enjoyed being in a nice quiet boutique hotel in an ideal location in Ginza. While the rooms are small, they are clean with comfortable beds and a nice walk in shower and separate soaking tub to help compensate for their lack of an onsen. What's great about the Solaria is its location. Its just a 2 minute walk to the Higashi-Ginza subway station, a five minute walk to the Mitsukoshi department store, and a short 10 minute walk to the Tsukiji outer fish market which is still in operation and just as vibrant as before. There are lots of restaurants in the area, including the #1 rated nodoguro fish restaurant in Tokyo just across the street from the hotel. Expensive, but its the best fish you'll ever eat in Japan. Last time I didn't enjoy the hotel’s odd breakfast buffet which provided only salad, juice and coffee on the buffet line and a choice of three fixed breakfast plates that they serve you. But this time, they added fruit, yogurt and panna cotta to the buffet table and you now have 4 different breakfast plates to choose from. Surprisingly, they were all good and quite satisfying even though you still can't get more unless you want more salad, fruit, yogurt, panna cotta or coffee. If that doesn't work, you can always go to Family Mart a block away to find something to eat. While the front desk staff speak little English, you can still figure it out. They earnestly try to help which is all that you can ask for. While the rooms are getting worn and could use a fresh new look, its still a clean, comfortable, reasonably priced hotel to enjoy your stay in Ginza.

I have travelled Tokyo several times and Ginza is my first priority staying location. By around 10 mins walk, we can walk to fish market directly. Downstairs have high end shopping mall and restaurant such as central area in HK while the price is reasonable having a comfortable stay. This would be my recommended choices to everyone

best location in Ginza, price and quality excellent, personal staff very kind with me, they advise and help me a lot. bed are very comfortobales, bathroom perfect and clean, I recomend, next time any doubt, Iwill come back

The Solaria Noshitetsu is located in the elegant Ginza, the luxury shopping district and one of the best neighborhoods due to its proximity to all the places of greatest interest!The rooms are well looked after, sometimes small but it depends a lot on the type of reservation you make although in Japan it is quite frequent. What will hit you is above all the cleaning!!!Breakfast is not continental: a selection of dishes is offered in line with Japanese customs and it is not surprising that there are dishes such as onion soup, cod fillet or raw beef. However you will also find roots, jellies, fruit, smoothies and dairy products such as panna cotta! Don’t worry a few meters from the hotel there is a starbucks!!!The staff is very respectful and courteous and the desk will help you for anything you need as booking taxi, restaurant or give you information about places and transport. In summary, a very good hotel, in Italy would be classified as a 3 or 4 stars.Marzio from Rome

I came to to Tokyo with my aunt and we stayed in the Hollywood Twin - Non Smoking room for 4 nights. The room size was a bit larger than normal hotels in the Ginza area, since we were able to open up our large luggage and lay it flat down on the floor. The bathroom was comfortable since it was a larger bathroom with separate bathroom and shower area. The location is fantastic because we were right across the street from Ippudo ramen in the heart of Ginza. Would definitely stay here again the next time I’m in town. But one thing the hotel needs to work on is responding to emails, might need a bit of a room touch up soon since a few corners of the rooms seems a bit tired.

We stayed overnight in Ginza and arrived with our room already prep and waiting for us. The staff speaks fluent English and very welcoming. The place is a short distance walk from a Metro station and the surrounding area has lots of restaurants and shops. Will recommend this hotel is your journey brings you to Ginza. This is a well kept hotel.

review_body: It’s a nice hotel with a good room size in Tokyo. The decor is modern and is in a good relocation - easy to get around. It’s nice and clean and the staff are friendly and helpful. There are cafes around. I would visit again.

You are paying for the location for this hotel. The hotel is in the middle of Ginza, with great access to the shops. The rooms are quite dated and in need of a makeover. The staff also weren’t as helpful and welcoming as the staff in other hotels we experienced across Japan.

This is not a 5* hotel presumably because it does not have a full service restaurant. But it felt like one due to the well designed and maintained rooms. Lovely place to stay in central Kyoto for a reasonable price.Would recommend to anyone

Great hotel at a very good location. Stayed in a triple room. The room size is of Tokyo’s standard.. with very little room to move around as expected of Tokyo’s hotel. A very short walk to both Ginza & Higashi-ginza station. Amenities provided in the room is excellent.. replenish daily. They paid special attention for the little kids need too. Very satisfied

The room was very well appointed with (unusual for this price range) a separate and comfortable sitting area where you can also enjoy a takeaway meal, which incidentally had a safe hidden beneath the sofa. The location is good with shops all around, including a department store. The hotel provides a free smart phone which was very handy for directions. They called a taxi for me to take me to Tokyo station (where I was to catch the Shinkansen to Kyoto) whilst I relaxed in the lobby until it arrived, and carrying my luggage for me when it did which was good service.

We stay here regularly because of the location near shops, restaurants and convenience stores. It's a 3 minute walk to the major shopping streets in the posh Ginza neighborhood (Matsuya department store, Chanel, Fendi, etc.). There are 2 Starbucks branches within 3 minutes walk. While it is possible to take a direct subway from Haneda airport to the hotel (the nearest subway stop "Higashi Ginza" is one minute away and you don't have to change trains), this 30 minute option requires you to carry your luggage up the subway staircase (exit A8). We opted instead for a 25 minute taxi ride at a cost of JPY 7,800.I agree with a previous reviewer about the service being barely average from the Japanese staff. It seemed that they were unwilling to help us because of the language barrier, though they were unfailingly polite at all times. There was only one receptionist who spoke passable English and helped us with restaurant reservations upon arrival. (our request to reserve restaurants prior to arrival, via email, was denied)The rooms are definitely compact if you are used to US-sized hotel rooms. Our floor space in our twin room was barely big enough to open my luggage. However, they were neat and tidy, with all the amenities you could think of (hair cuticle oil, face wash and a decent hair conditioner). If you are an independent traveler like me and don't require much assistance from the front desk, then this is central hotel would probably suit you as a practical base. For a holiday treat, I would look at the 4* Millennium Mitsui hotel, which is a short stroll away.

I was pleased with this boutique hotel in terms of location in central Ginza, easy walk to the fish market. It was quite pleasure to be able to walk out of the hotel in be so centrally located-in the midst of busy Ginza, yet the street on the hotel was on was quiet and low key. The rooms were compact more so than the pictures, Suitcases had to be stacked to walk around and it was tight with two people. The bathroom was clean, well proportioned and I loved having a separate shower/bath area.The service- the front desk staff always was respectful and tried hard to help, however at times they were unable to help us with what we needed- One example, a friend got sick while there and the front desk staff could not locate an English speaking doctor in the area, or anywhere in Tokyo, or followed up to see if we were ok- I would expect a hotel of that size to at least have a few names to refer to. We unfortunately had to leave early because of this illness and didn't get any credit on multiple nights. I have been in situations where I've had to leave early and have had more understanding on the part of the hotel staff.

review_body: We were part of a family group of 7 adults and one baby occupying 4 rooms. Me and wife's specific room was the double room, which was exceedingly small though clean.The only complaint was the unhelpful though polite front desk staffs. Not really having much initiative and not service oriented. Manager was also unhelpful.Recommend to choose larger rooms and upgrade staff training.

Early check-in is chargeable if you arrive before 3pm regardless of room being ready or not so just left our bags behind reception Thereafter we found the hotel comfortable and well located and staff helpful . There’s a Taxi rank right outside and so is a highly rated Ramen restaurant (cheap eats not gourmet! ) Would recommend

Room is pretty tiny and it didn't help that they have a couch squeezed into the tiny space. Photos of room look better online than in reality. The facade of the hotel looks really stylish but the room was a pretty far cry. The bathtub uses a dated shower curtain instead of those modern glass doors in contemporary hotels. On the positive side they do provide the necessary bathroom amenities.No english channels on TV except BBC. They do provide a mobile phone/tablet that you can bring out which allows free internet access and calls to a handful of countries. They provide only 2 bottles of water a day. I tried to ask for an extra bottle of water and was flat out rejected. The only thing I love about the hotel is the location and proximity to Ginza station. Overall, it is a pretty fuss free hotel that is relatively clean. I noticed many Japanese guests. Do not expect a hip and contemporary boutique hotel with state of the art amenities like how it is being portrayed in online photos.

My husband and I stayed here for 5 nights in April 2018. It was the final leg of our three week tour through Japan and we were ready to stay put on one spot instead of changing accomodation as regularly as we had been.Right off the bat we had to ask about changing rooms...we were checked into 902 and it was tiny beyond words, even for just one person. We barely had room to store our luggage and we really didn't have an excessive amount to begin with. The hotel had no rooms available for two nights so we moved as soon as we could. The second room (912) was much better, albeit still pretty small.We only had breakfast in the hotel but there was plenty of variety and we always had our choice of set meals with lots of extras. Overall I would recommend this hotel because of it's location in Ginza, but definitely check the size of the room before you get too settled in.

The Solaria hotel is a nice, modern 13 floor hotel in an ideal location in Ginza. The rooms are small but very efficient and tastefully furnished. The separate shower and soaking tub provide a great way to unwind after a hard day of sightseeing and shopping. The hotel is just a couple minute walk from the Higashi-Ginza subway station and a five minute walk from the Mitsukoshi department store. The famous tsukiji fish market is just a ten minute walk from the hotel. There are lots of restaurants in the area, but be sure to go early since all the good ones get crowded real fast. The hotel’s breakfast buffet is odd. Only salad, juice and coffee are on the buffet line. You only have a choice of three different breakfast menus and you can’t get more unless you want more salad, coffee or juice. Weird. You can always go to Lawson’s or Family Mart nearby to pick up breakfast instead.

I tried this Solaria since the one in Kyoto was nice. This one is the total opposite. The rooms are dated and there are scatched and chipped furniture and decor. The bathroom is worn and the bidet is not heated. The window panes are not sound proof and you hear rowdy noises from bar patrons at night, a doorbell noise from a security motion detector, and street noises like ambulances. It isn't located on the main road but somehow it's very noisy. Our room was on the 7th floor. I usually stayed at the hotel in front of it, Tokyu Stay Ginza, which is quite good. This hotel looks nice from the outside but the rooms badly need some updating. The pictures from Expedia and Travelocity makes the room look new and modern, but it's not. Overall, I would not stay here again.

This is my preferred hotel when in Tokyo. Great location, great staff, acceptable room size at a reasonable price. I was there end of March 2018 and had an in room incident. The response and actions taken by the staff was very effective and heartfelt. I will go back again later this fall to Solaria.

Stayed here for 4 nights back in October and fell in love with this hotel. Booked the single room and found it to be of decent size and very comfortable for one person. All the necessary amenities are in place. Though the room does not have any windows but I am fine with that. Staff are all friendly and helpful. Location is perfect! Literally steps away from the Ginza shopping strips and the subway. Surrounded by many restaurants, convenient stores and ATMs. Walking distance to the famous Tsukiji Fish Market.

I had booked this hotel because of my excellent experience in her sister hotel in Myeongdong, Seoul. The stay in Solaria Nishitetsu Myeongdong was perfect with a clean room, great service and comfortable stay. I was regretful for bringing such expectations to the Solaria Nishitetsu Ginza. The room was generally much smaller than the one I had in Seoul and the walls were not clean - still stained with spills left by a previous resident. The humidifier was unusable - it was spewing air with a fishy smell from it. I believed the filter of the humidifier was not changed at all. The heater was too hot even at 24*C and therefore had to open the windows to mix the cold air with the heat. But it was a wrong decision as it was really noisy due to the Ippudo queue just opposite the hotel.Counter staff were not as friendly as the Seoul's staff. They were minimally English-speaking. Quite disappointing especially when the hotel is situated in Ginza.

We are booked to arrive at the hotel in mid April. We have a plan to visit famous restaurants and trying to book in advance, but facing challenges as most restaurants don’t have English speaking staff. I spoke to the hotel and they refused to assist with restaurant bookings. By the time we get there, the restaurants will be fully booked. Bad experience already!

We had privacy, clean, silent room with the view - just what we've been looking for. Location is nice too, business zone, by foot you can reach cool locations. Breakfast was excluded so cannot ssy nothing about it.

Room is tidy and clean. 50m walk to convenient store and train station. Less than 200m walk to main Ginza street. Alot of good food around the hotel. The nearest train station exist to hotel is A2 (no escalator)

only location is good in Ginza, close to tube n shopping. room is small, said to be 24 sq m but not so useful, compared with similar size hotel in Tokyo. front desk is poor, when u ask to help, just said as noted in the paper. why I need to stay here? other hotels will not like that. Ask to help to book a taxi upon checkout, the girl reluctant to help! always need to ask for senior to solve. avoid & not recommend for stay!

We chose this hotel because of the location. No doubt the location is golden!! In the heart of Ginza. Less than 2 min. Walks to Higashi Ginza subway station. Unfortunately the day we went back home, weather wasn't exactly good. One of the heaviest snowed in 4yrs in Tokyo. Since I went for holiday with my wife and my son, we have 2 large luggage, 1 medium luggage and 3 cabin bag luggages. I ask one of the front office staff to call us 2 cabs, but they have extremely very hard time to tell me that taxi that day is can't be reserved due to heavy demand. What pisses me off, one of the staff is just standing there with extremely 'sour face'. Other staff (again with very limited English) still trying to call the taxi company but again no luck. I ask for them for help, cause I desperately need to go to catch a bus to the airport. But no one seems wants to help. I have to stand for more than 25 min in the middle of snow storm just to catch a taxi. Btw, I stayed for total 6 nights and I book two rooms. Other than that, the room is perfectly normal. Room is Japanese standard. Housekeeping is extremely polite and helpful. Even though they don't speak much English, but they still very polite. Maybe the Front Office should learn some basic manner from the Housekeeping. Definitely won't come back here!!

My wife and I stayed here while on vacation. Right in the centre of Ginza, easy walk to everything, and close to the metro line if you want to go further afield. The rooms are small as you would expect, but very comfortable and well laid out, with everything you need. Breakfast in the restaurant is excellent food. (Could do better coffee). The staff at the front desk are very helpful and friendly, and will go out of their way to make recommendations and give you detailed directions. No gym, which is something I like in a hotel, but sometimes you can’t have everything.

We had a family trip over the year end and through my daughter’s research and my Japanese friend’s counsel, we picked this hotel for its location (Ginza, 3 min walk from the subway station) and cost. Due to its popularity, check in time was not negotiable but we soon found that everything else was spot on, from the room size (small by Asian standards but adequate), cleanliness, bed quality and especially the bathroom (sizeable and fully functional). I rate them a full 5 stars!There was however one (small) downside - there is a restaurant but no bar in the hotel. So waiting for family members and having a pre-dinner drink was not so easy ;). And the fact that ther was no gym didn’t go down too well with my wife. Anyhow all in all, however excellent and will certainly be going back!

This Ginza district (high street fashion and shopping area) hotel is quite central yet quietly located and inexpensive. It is 3-5 min walking to various subway stations. It is also 11min walking to the famous Tsukiji Fish Market.Coming from the Haneda airport is easy: You take Keikyu-Kuko line, get off at Higashi-Ginza station and exit at A2 to walk about 3 min. In total27min you are at Solaria Nishitetsu.Our room was about 15m2. Rather small yet super clean and brand new with abundant amenities and same day return laundry. If you have too many luggages and need all you belongings in the room, this may be a challenge!The breakfast offers both continental and japanese food. Nothing luxurious but practical and proper.The staff was quite helpful and welcoming. Especially the nearby izakaya reference they mentioned at the time of our check in (after a loooong flight) was perfect. You need to be patient with the English communication, though. If you are looking for a hotel with an energizing lobby, roof-top-bar, in house shops, this is not your place. You are free to book some other 5-star deluxe properties.We are looking fwd to returning back to this hotel. Many thx Solaria Nishitetsu team.

Quiet and comfortable room. Nice staff. The hotel is situated 200m from the subway with express trains heading to Haneda airport in 40 minutes.The hotel is in the heart of Ginza, allowing you to discover the neighbourhood.A lot of sights are by walking distance (Imperial palace, Tsukiji market).Hotel highly recommended for those wanting to stay in Ginza during their trip to Tokyo.

When people asked me where I was staying in Tokyo, they were mostly shocked that I was staying in what is the high end area of Tokyo. But I must say I got a very good deal with Solaria!I chose this hotel due to the proximity to my conference venue, and my usual 'hotel' criteria that it has to be convenient. I booked the single room and was abit worried about the frosted windows instead of clear see through windows. But once I reached the hotel and realised the windows could openly slightly, I was happy. For a hotel in central Tokyo, I honestly thought the room was of a very very good size. I mean, it even had a shower AND bathtub. I loved how the washroom/shower area was partitioned, one area each for the sink, toilet and shower. The sink area even came with a chair!It also had all the amenities you would require - a mini fridge, kettle, toiletries, free bottled water, everything. The service was also impeccable - as I had requested for a late check out, I did not want housekeeping to enter my room on my last day. But yet, they still made sure to leave a whole bag of toiletries, including change of bathrobe and towels for me at the door. I thought that was a very sweet gesture. The location is also hard to beat - two convenience stores, two Starbucks, Mcdonalds, cafes all within 5 mins walking distance. The Ginza station is also about 3 mins away. But yet the hotel is tucked away maybe 1 block away from all the hustle and bustle, so you are convenient enough wihout being bothered by the people and noise.

We stayed hear the last weekend in October. Room was small but more than adequate. No place to put large bags, but we managed. We were there when a typhoon hit so our plans to travel around Tokyo for sightseeing were crimped. We were able to do some major shopping and eating within walking distance with umbrellas

I found the Solaria nishitetsu on tripadvisor. My main destination was Osaka and environs so this was my arrival and departure hotel for Japan. My husband and I were extremely happy with the location of the hotel which allowed us to walk to and from the subway for our Haneda airport flights, and to walk to the train station for the trip to Osaka, although the train station might be outside what some would consider an acceptable walking distance. We found nearby restaurants, coffee, and convenience stores all within a few blocks of the hotel on safe, well lit streets. The room for both stays was small (what room in Japan is not?), functional and very clean. The rooms had extra towels and toiletries, a room safe, new slippers and pajamas on the bed for guest use, hair dryer, etc. We did not want for anything. Wifi access was good, and we did not watch TV. The staff was very friendly. The restaurant was lovely, but somewhat expensive. We only ate there once. I am recommending this hotel to others, and will stay at the Solaria on my return trips to Tokyo.

Chose this hotel due to it's location. Booked a single room and it was good but small. The room is clean and comfortable (apart from the toilet which was a little too cozy). There was an air-purifier in the room which was good. The house-keeping staff were all very friendly but don't speak any English. Rooms are cleaned from 10am onwards and you are able to hear a fair bit through the room door (e.g. vacuuming). There are 2 English channels on TV but the WiFi connectivity was strong. The staff at the front desk are very nice and can help if you need any recommendations. The hotel is a 5-minute walk to the train station and lots of restaurants and convenience stores nearby. A reasonably priced stay for Ginza but quite basic.

You could give this place 5 stars for the location alone. Just a block away from the Mitsuoka Department store and minutes walk from Ginza station and all the brand stores, you’ll find yourself in the thick of the action at the Solaria.But once you add in the fact the combination of the affordability and quality of the rooms, I think you’ll find yourself hard pressed to find another choice in Ginza or any other neighbourhood with such great value.If you’re looking to be in Ginza and want something reliable that doesn’t break the bank, you can’t do much better than the Solaria.

This hotel was recommended by a friend and didn't disappoint. The hotel is in an incredibly convenient location within a couple of minutes walk to the main intersection in Ginza with Matsuya and Mitsukoshi department stores right there along with a multitude of other amazing stores and restaurants. I love shopping in Japan so it was heaven for someone like me!Ginza and Higashi Ginza subway lines are also a couple of minutes walk away providing easy access to other areas in Tokyo. JR yurakucho and shimbashi stations are also an easy 10 min walk.We have stayed/lived in many different locations in Tokyo and would have to say this is the most convenient location in view of transport links, food and shopping. The hotel is modern, clean and well laid out. We booked a twin room as it was larger than a double. The room is small at 24sqm, however this is common with similarly priced hotels like Park hotel and Royal park in Shiodome. The beds can be pushed together to create a bit of extra floor space for suitcases and the bed is very comfortable, not too hard.The bathroom is really well designed. It is not high rise so don't expect views from your room and being a smaller hotel the lobby/reception is small. The restaurant has a great value buffet for breakfast , just disappointing to have to pay 600yen extra to get cappuccino or espresso when you're a coffee snob!We would highly recommend the hotel for a first time visit or frequent visitors to Japan.

I stayed in the Solaria 2 times. 1 in 2013 and one in 2017 during the summer. I forgot I stayed here before so I was a bit bummed when i walked over ( 20 min walk from Tokyo station) and entered cause I remembered it as a decent place but for some reason not my favorite. They must have renovated or I chose a better room because it was great. just great! The room had a double bed and while the view was in the back and windows were tinted the bathroom was huge with full tub and window to room. Great internet and clean and really A good place if you get the larger rooms. I'm not sure if I stayed in a different size room ( I don't think so ) Or if the room is larger cause it is in the back with no real view ( unless you crack the window) but it was great. The location is great. An easy walk to Tsukiji , Ginza, Shimbashi, Closed Ginza street on weekends. Just great. I do wish the window was not blurred out and that is my only complaint, but i was near the fire escape so there was a reason etc. You can't go wrong with 1 person or a couple here. It would have been just ok for our son for 1-2 nights at most in the double room..as well, but not sure if they have cribs. GO FOR IT!

Boutique hotel positioned conveniently in a lovely neighbourhood of Tokyo which does all of the basics very well. We paid around AUD$230/night for a Twin Room and for this price this hotel was excellent value. Room size was larger than other hotels and staff were friendly and helpful. Close to the fish market which is great if you're thinking about doing the early morning Tuna auction. Great area to stay as a couple or family with plenty of food and bar options close by without being directly in the madness of Shinjuku or Shibuya. No bells and whistles of a 5 star hotel like gyms and spa facilities but what they do, they do very well. Stay here!

My daughter and I stayed at the Solaria nishitetsu hotel in the Ginza for 5 nights and we loved it. Fantastic location in Ginza a block from main shopping street. The first Starbucks in Ginza is very close for breakfast coffee. Very smart boutique hotel, lovely room and great toiletries . We could walk out every day and we were in the heart of Ginza. Highly recommended for a special stay!

Stayed at Solaria for a total of 5 nights with my family. Staff was helpful in making reservations and brief recommendation on dining places around Ginza. Perfectly convenient location for anyone with kids or on a shopping trip. However, A male staff was especially impolite upon our departure to the airport this morning. After checking out, we booked a vehicle and were waiting at the hotel's entrance. He came out to ask for a room key card and demanded for us to pay for breakfast. Breakfast has been paid for, and his colleague has acknowledged that. We would have expected a "Thank You, see u again." , rather than such a demanding attitude. Without even checking, he was so confident in his demands. This was perhaps the most disappointing part of our experience with Solaria.

Excellent location within easy walking distance of three metro/ JR stations. The room was very comfortable and clean. The staff were very friendly and helpful and all spoke English well. Breakfast selection was a bit limited but the food was good quality.

You get what you pay for. The hotel is a no fuss hotel from check-in to check out.Friendly staffs and clean rooms. Probably my only concern is the small toilet space. However this is only a minor stay. Slept good (due to early flight to Tokyo?)The buffet breakfast is just okay with some unique dishes offered.

Great location, only 2 blocks of the main street in Ginza corner with the apple store. The staff was very helpful and the hotel very clean. Very well communicated, close to Ginza station and the Oi Oi Moll.

We stayed here for 5 nights, and although the room was small (but normal by Tokyo standards), it was quite comfortable with an excellent location. The hotel itself was initially difficult to find, but that's also normal for Tokyo standards - what helped us was seeing the name on the side of the building from a couple blocks away.The service is excellent. Speaking no Japanese, I was initially concerned about the staff's English skills after reading reviews, but fear not - the staff's English is excellent. The check-in and check-out process was very quick and easy, and our room was ready before the 3pm check in. They were also very helpful with providing information to areas around the hotel and getting to/from the airport (the Narita bus stops just about 3-4 blocks away, so you don't need to drag your bags to Tokyo Station, which is just under a mile away).The room, as mentioned earlier, was quite small. We had a king bed, and the images of rooms with two doubles show a considerably larger room. The room was excellent though - the bathrooms were especially good - and it was very quiet and the beds were very comfortable. There is no dresser or storage for your clothes, only a very shallow closet, so keep that in mind. My wife and I are okay in tighter spaces, so it didn't bother us too much. The television, for English speakers, only had one channel - BBC World - and about 10 other stations in Japanese.The location of this hotel and its good price make this a great selection for your next trip to Tokyo. There are two Starbucks within 2 blocks, there's a food court nearby and plenty of high-end shopping in the neighborhood. The Ginza subway stop is just two blocks away (look for exit 12), and if you are going onwards any further, we found it easier to walk directly to Tokyo Station rather than take the Ginza line from Ginza to Tokyo, which seemed to have just as much walking in underground metro tunnels.

This hotel is in an excellent location, and close to the subway, shops, fish market, restaurants, etc.As with the other hotels on our trip, my husband and I stayed in a twin room as they were larger than the double rooms. Our room in this hotel was probably the smallest room we stayed in, but that's to be expected given the location.As with our other hotels, our room was completely sound-proof and the air-conditioning was silent and effective (something that is sadly too rare, in our experience.) I loved the large walk-in shower and the bath products.I also enjoyed the breakfast area which was attractive and comfortable, and the breakfast buffet was the best we experienced on our trip.

Small room but that's to be expected in a big city. Great central location in Ginza. 10 minutes/1000yen ($9) taxi ride from Tokyo Central station. Half a mile from fish market but situated in a high-end area. Great attention to detail in room design and supply: examples include robes for sleeping, toiletries, and bath salts. As perhaps in all of Japan, great high-tech toilets and fogless bathroom mirrors :) the sweetest and most polite staff you can imagine. Very nice breakfast breakfast spread--I recommend including it in your reservation to save.

First time to Tokyo and this hotel did not disappoint. The rooms are tiny but super nice. You have everything you need in a teeny space - very comfy and clean. Loved the compact design and the energy efficiency. The skin products they placed in the room were lovely and the tub is way better than American designs. The lobby is nice and the staff was helpful. An AMAZING ramen restaurant right around the corner and lots of fun places to visit nearby. Close to the fish market, shopping, and dining. Priced right.

Very conveniently located in Ginza near the Ginza and Higashiginza subway stations, also 10 mins walking distance to Yurakucho JR Station. Very compact, very efficient in every way. Breakfast was fresh and just enough. The room, although small, had everything efficiently placed and was clean and thoughtful. Try the cream puff bakery right across the street, it was delicious!

We enjoyed our stay in the hotel and it's convenient location in the Ginza. Great Ramen just across the road. One problem was the lack of English speaking staff at Reception. They try hard, however.....I can see this as an issue during the World Cup Rugby and the 2022 Olympics. Rooms are cosy at best especially with luggage. Beds are really comfortable but with no side access as against a wall. No Onsen in hotel.

We stayed at this hotel the last few days of our trip and it was nice to stay in a different area of Tokyo from the start of our trip. Though not very convenient to the city loop trains (Yamanote Line - free for JR Pass holders), there was a metro station just down the block. The hotel was stylish and comfortable and the staff helpful. We had a corner room which gave the impression that there was lots of room. By this point we were addicted to the Japanese baths and used the deep tub alcove and bath salts to the fullest extent!

This hotel located in ginza. All the high end brand name shop are with in walking distance. Like 15 mins can reach 有楽町area. This is a perfect place for shopping. Convinence shop just around corner. Big department shop just behind the hotel

A small boutique hotel with small rooms especially for 2 people with luggage. We always stay here before going on a cruise for Tokyo harbor. Although the front desk people spoke little English, I found it easy to communicate with them. The hotel is in the heart of Ginza, the major shopping area in Japan. It's centrally located to almost everything including train station and cruise ship terminal. Although you can get meals at the hotel, I always eat out.

The blanket and pillows are made of real feathers. You can ask at the reception to provide a synthetic cover instead, but no synthetic pillow. Good location: within 15 mins walk from the Tokyo station, close to different underground lines, the Tsukiji market and the Kabuki theatre; lots of luxury shops around. The single rooms are not well designed - the toilet and bathroom are on the side of the windows which are obscured with white film; there are some curtains but they don´t fully block out light. Standard rooms are laid out normally and have ligh-blocking curtains.

Solaria hotel is a clean, cozy and in the most amazing spot hotel with a value for money satisfying rate. The fact that it is in the heart of Tokyo, so close to anything anyone might need makes it even more useful. We did not have breakfast at the hotel, as nearby there are millions of little stores where you can have a nice breakfast and a nice coffee.

Everything about the hotel is perfect for a single traveller (rooms are small, but not a problem for one person) and the location is superb! My only minor complaint is that the very polite, well-intentioned front desk staff was always a chore to deal with for two reasons: 1) their English skills were VERY limited, and I say this not as some "dumb American" expecting everyone else to speak English -- I have studied and speak three foreign languages fluently myself, but not Japanese -- but as someone expecting that any hotel in the cosmopolitan, business-central Ginza District would be aware that a vast majority of guests from around the world might ONLY have English as a common communication means between each other...and 2) they were unaware of and ill-equipped to answer what I saw as some of the most common, basic tourist questions (i.e. how subway fares are purchased, where to catch a hop-on-hop-off tour bus, where the closest conveyor belt sushi restaurant is, how to get to a major performing arts center, or how to buy tickets for the Tokyo Sky Tree attraction). Almost every question I posed was greeted first by a blank stare and then 10-15 minutes of 2-3 desk staff people scurrying around doing research on the Internet and printing out useless pages of information. At one point, they even suggested I ask my questions to the neighborhood 7-Eleven!? This, as I told the hotel manager, is unacceptable in a hotel at the center of a major business district.

New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is perfectly located - walk out exit A13 of the Ginza station or exit A2 of the Higashiya-ginza station and in a minute you would be there. You can reach anywhere in Tokyo within 30 mins and the plus point - theres an express from Haneda or Narita airport direct to/from Higashiya-ginza. Ginza is a world famous shopping district - you would find different cuisines, lots of coffee shops, grocery stores and anything that you might need in the area around the hotel.  The rooms, though small, are to japanese standard sizes. We were in a twin sharing room of 23 sq.m. and had two medium sized suitcases - it was difficult to keep both open at the same time. However, they were super clean (even the toilets) and super comfortable. Please do keep in mind - the hotel does not allow an earlier check-in or a late check-out.This probably might be the only downside of the hotel. However, the hotel does hold your luggage for few hours until you get room/its time to head to the airport.

This new hotel in Ginza was recommended by my friend. It is very Clean. We had good breakfast every morning in the hotel. It is a short walking distance to train station where we can go to different places like shibuya, shinjuku, roponggi, harajuku, etc. The bus station to AMD from Narita airport is a few steps from this hotel which makes it convenient for us. Good restaurants like ippudo ramen and ikinari steak are just right across the hotel. Very convenient and central.

Stayed @ the Solaria a number of times over the years for 3 reasons - Location, price and quality. You can't beat that it is in the middle of Ginza (100m or so off the main drag). For price, again for the quality you get it's heads and shoulders above other hotels in the area and the quality - Still feels like a new hotel and the service is good/consistent. Highly recommended for those looking for a cheaper option in downtown Tokyo! Oh, and internet is free - Bonus!

We had a wonderful time for our three nights in elegant Ginza. We were within walking distance to Tokyo station. Our package included a delicious continental breakfast in classy surroundings. The two rooms were very comfortable and modern with everything we needed. Our teenage boys slept in the twin room next to our double which had a more spacious bathroom than ours, much to their delight.The staff were polite and spoke enough English to cater for us overseas travellers. We would definitely stay there again.

Among many mid range hotel in this area, this hotel is popular because of good value for money. Though it is located in the middle of Ginza, a popular shopping district, the room is relatively spacious and the price is reasonable. All facilities are modern and the service is ok. This is more for business or quick holiday hotel.

I booked this hotel with Chase Points and figured it would be fine, but you never know. I was pleasantly surprised to find the outside of the hotel and the lobby were very nice, and while the rooms were small by American standards, it's important to remember this is Japan we're talking about. Things are more...compact. We had a room with two twin beds and it felt like a really spacious cruise ship cabin, so it had more than enough space for us to sleep and shower...you're not in Tokyo to hang out in your room anyway. The shower area was actually the most spacious part of the room, and the water pressure was awesome. Hotel and room were very clean and quiet, despite being centrally located. Kagari Ginza down the street is a fantastic hidden gem of a ramen restaurant - stay at Solaria, eat at Kagari, and you're set. :)

Superb location in Ginza,which just one block behind Matsuya. For stations, easily reached from Ginza and Higashi Ginza. Small building but once you entered, well designed lobby, two smoothly working elevators, and the rooms are spacious compared to the other same level hotels in Ginza, especially the bathroom! Breakfast also was good with choice of Japanese and western. However, for staying more than 3 days, maybe you will have the 4th breakfast outside the hotel. Overall great hotel and will stay again here for sure!

Have stayed in Ginza three times and this is the best value budget/mid range (for Ginza!) hotel I have stayed in. Bigger than average rooms, fantastic location for Ginza station (exit A13) and Higashi Ginza Station (exit A2) and close to everything you need. Great restaurants a short walk away. and Tsukiji market just a 10 min walk down the road.Excellent reception staff.

Hotel was really nice and clean,rooms were small but not relatively to this part of Tokyo.Facilities are very modern.Staff wasn't very nice or helpful, nobody really spoke english.Laundry service is very expansive, we used a laundromat instead.

The room is spacious when you compare with other hotels in Japan. And, it's location is perfect as it's only few minutes to nearby metro stations. As this trip is mainly for shopping & eating, I have lots of choices at nearby department stores & restaurants.Moreover, it's only 10-15 minutes walking distance to Tsukiji Market. Staff at front desk can speak English well that communication is not a problem at all.I will definitely recommend this hotel to my friends & will stay again next time in Tokyo.

We recently stayed at Solaria Nishitetsu Hotel Ginza for the first time. The hotel is located close to Higashi-Ginza and Ginza Stations. This was particularly convenient for transportation from Haneda Airport, since the Keikyu train (which turns into Tokyo Metro train eventually) stops at Higashi-Ginza. Therefore, we were able to get to the hotel without doing any transfer. Also, the new (?) express bus service from/to Narita Airport stops at northern Ginza, about 5-10 min walk from the hotel. The hotel is close to both Mitsukoshi and Matsuya department stores, as well as the whole fancy Ginza shopping district. There are small shops and restaurants all over the area as well. The hotel is very attractive with very helpful front desk staff with excellent English skills. Our room was clean and very attractive. The size of the room is typical of Japanese hotels. I highly recommend this hotel.

Quiet location within Ginza close to all the shopping and excellent restaurants. The room is comfortable and well appointed though typically small. Has free wifi TV and the usual mod cons. The hotel has excellent English speaking service. Checkout is 11 AM and when we arrived they allowed us to check in at 1PM though usually its 3 PM

Hotel location is very convenient and located in the pricey side of the city. 3 mins walk to Mitsukoshi Nihonbashi department store where the food court down on level B1 was fantastic and not to be missed. The room is clean but small which I guess is very typical in Tokyo. One thing that bothered me a little is the toilet in the bathroom, the flush is not very powerful due to the effort of water conservation but it can cause problems because we ended up having to flush multiple times. The front desk staffs speak adequate English, we didn't have any issue with communicating.

Quiet, comfortable hotel with helpful staff right in main Tokyo shopping district. Excellent Japanese buffet breakfast with Western touches. Great value for such a nice hotel. Next door to Ippudon noodles restaurant with great local fare. Just a ten minute walk to Tsuchiki fish market for super fresh seafood of all varieties.

I've been to Tokyo a couple of times now, and I've come to conclusion that my favorite place to stay is at Solaria Hotel Ginza. Not only is it in the middle of Ginza, but it is affordable, highly maintained, and also walking distance to the Tokyo Metro.

I travel for work, and really appreciate finding places I want to return to. Hotel Solaria in Ginza is one of my favorite places. The rooms are more spacious than most hotels in Japan, and include a nice work desk area, breakfast at the restaurant on the 2nd floor, great location, and friendly staff that is able to speak English. I've stayed here several times and gladly recommend it.

Stayed for three nights. Excellent comfortable beds and good pillows. Great bathtub that came with various bath salts and stuff. Clean and well maintained. Front staff with limited English but trying their best.Room Japanese size smallish but OK (if a bit tight) with two giant suitcases and two people in twin room. Silent hotel and silent ac/heating.So so breakfast with somewhat limited selection (eg one black tea and one green and 650 Yen for a cappuccino) However the croissants require special mentioning as they were really really good.Many free umbrellas for borrow in the reception. When travelling to the airport (both) the closest metro is only 30 m from the hotel entrance just outside the Family Mart which is extremely convenient.The ice cream/cake parlour "Celi" on the corner opposite is worth a visit.Would stay again.

I needed to stay in Ginza due to work but I also wanted to be on a budget and I found Solaria for about $150/night. In Japan, there is a particular "businessman's hotel" which is sort of standardized. I guess you can consider it sort of like a hilton type model, as many of them are chains, however, Japanese standards are not like other standards, and these hotels are quite amazing and good and many of them are very well designed. They feel more like boutique hotels rather than a chain, especially the lobby and lounge areas. The only issue to watch out for is size of the rooms, but fortunately, Solaria was a totally normal sized room with a little sofa and desk area. Since I am only 5 feet tall, proportions don't matter as much to me, but I found this hotel quite adequate. both nights I had a bath in the very deep tubs and I found the hotel room bright and quiet. This hotel comes with the standard amenities of a business hotel (meaning, everything!!!) bath salts, toothbrushes, shampoos, and a million other amenities you probably didn't realize you needed in the bathroom. I did not eat the breakfast, but instead walked straight to tsujiki which is only about 10 minutes away for 830 am sushi and walked the markets. The hotel location is actually quite quite fabulous. very close to ginza train stations which there are several options, and about 900 yen taxi ride to Tokyo station. It's just removed from all the hustle and bustle of ginza, yet still extremely convenient. Mitsukoshi department store is right next door where you can go to the food halls in the basement(everyone needs to experience a department store food hall once in japan) and have some amazing local snacks and my fave stationary store K.itoya is close. There is a starbucks on every corner but there are also many better cafe's open (just not all of them open at 7 which is what I needed).

I stayed alone on the 9th floor. The room was clean, though oddly the toilet and bathroom are on the window side of the room, thus leaving it quite dark. The staff was friendly; breakfast was included and quite good (especially the eggplant sushi and croissants!). Great location as well!

This hotel is well located and easy to access from most areas. Only one restrarunt but plenty around. Room clean and service staff great and helpful. There were a little thrown when two women wanted to sleep in a double bed. It is also disappointing that if you arrive before 3 and your room is ready they expect a fee.Otherwise I would recommend it

Excellent hotel in a great part of Tokyo, steps from luxury shopping and great dining options. Rooms are small, but by Japan standards are quite spacious, and well-appointed. Extremely nice and comfortable hotel

Visited Tokyo in June. Very near the train station but other reviewers are correct - if you have luggage, use the exit with the elevator which is across the street from the hotel. You will have to roll all your luggage to cross the street then walk a little to get to the street of the hotel; it was really manageable. And coming from Haneda, the train stops in Ginza, no transfers. The fare was ¥610.Reserved 3 rooms for our family w/ bfast for 2 per room. Upon check in, without any prodding, the staff offered that the 2 kids with us would get free bfast. At bfast the next day, they didn't honor that, as in they acted like we were lying so since we didn't want to argue anymore we just signed for the kids. It took the front desk a day to tell us that they couldn't do anything as the owner of the Cafe is different from the owner of the hotel and they have their own rules. Huh??? Different policy for the Hotel Cafe??? So go figure haha. Anyway, the simple bfast was okay and filling even if it was the same the whole 6 days we were there - the breads were really good specially the mini chocolate Danish. Apart from the breakfast "misunderstanding", our stay at the hotel was good. The rooms were clean and we really liked the bathroom - others reviewers were right, the bathroom took up maybe 1/3 of the room so it was really comfortable. Rooms and bathrooms were very clean. The washroom at the lobby was even nicer than the one in the room - it was fully automatic in the same way as toilets in Japan but as you open the door, the toilet seat goes up. In the guest area downstairs there are also 2 computers with printer for the guests, as well as brochures and other tour pamphlets in English. You can also borrow umbrellas from the front desk.Behind the hotel is a shop which sells Yoga gear (I can't remember the name) and their bags are really nice. There was a Family Mart around the corner and a big drugstore that closes late and some vendo machines scattered around the hotel. You won't get hungry in that area, there are so many restaurants surrounding the hotel, like at least 2 per street (there's Japanese, Italian, Ramen, steak etc). There's a McDonald's 2 blocks away below Mercure Hotel, a Starbucks a few minutes from Solaria, a Lawson plus the Ramen restaurant right in front of the hotel. There are also 3 department stores in Ginza, we ate twice at Mitsukoshi, both at Japanese restaurants and both were really good. You can walk to all the shops in Ginza, everything is there. Aside from all the luxury brands and chain brands, there's a big music store - Yamaha near Zara and H&M. I think it has 12 floors and it had everything, guitars, straps, all sizes of amplifiers, music books. We only reached until the 3rd floor and we were there for more than 2 hours already. There's a money changer in Ginza at a building called Ginza Core, I think it's World Currency on the 5th floor of that bldg. Also, in case you need extra luggage and don't want to spend on expensive ones, they sell hard case luggage on the ground floor for only ¥5400, 3 sizes and different colors for the same price. Still on the ground floor, there's a store - Zoff - that's sells eyeglasses and sunglasses without or with prescription which you can claim 30 minutes to an hour after they check your eyes. The cheapest pairs, if I remember right, are sold for ¥7000 which includes prescription. They also make those with progressive ones but it will take more than a day. Tsukiji Market is also near the hotel, some family members walked there to eat and it took them 10 minutes. It's also just 1 station away from Ginza. Kabukiza Theatre is also just a little further down the street, with coffee shops on the ground floor while waiting for the show to start.

Well appointed rooms, good layout although not large rooms. Very clean and efficient housekeeping. Reception staff will do all to assist although some limitations with English. A good feeling of Tokyo as a clean, efficient, friendly and courteous city

Excellent rooms, small but normal size by Japanese standards. Very clean. Great staff. Only one restaurant which serves meals, but no all day dining or cafe. Also, no gym. Absolutely fantastic location! Definitely recommend it!

Clean & new,hotel is very close to the metro.10 mins walk to Tsukiji.You don't need to choose hotel breakfast instead have fresh fish(sushi) in Tsukiji every morning! How wonderful is that .The room is alittle be tiny but beautiful.

We stayed at Solaria for 9 nights in a twin room (larger than double and beds can be pushed together). Room was small but comfortable, had AC and air purifier/humidifier, and had a great shower and bath. Location is in Ginza central to shopping, great restaurants, Tsukiji market, and Kabuki-za, and is on Ginza line, which goes direct to Shibuya and Ueno/Asakusa. Tokyo station is in walking distance or brief taxi ride with luggage to catch Shinkansen, and Yurakucho JR station is also about a 10 minute walk. Staff were not all completely fluent in English but were all very kind and very willing and able to help with restaurant reservations and other needs. Hotel stored our luggage when we travelled outside of Tokyo for a few days mid-trip and had it waiting in our room when we returned. Overall a great stay, centrally located, and reasonably priced, especially for Tokyo.

In the heart of ginza.....walking distance from all brand name stores, restaurants and ginza station....u have nearby stores to get everything u want...free wifi...next to the hotel a really nice Ramen restaurant that open till 2am for late night cravings

In an amazing location surrounded by restaurants and shops. Good transport links, Ginza & Higashi Ginza subway stations close by. Very helpful English speaking staff too Main disadvantage is the size of the room but everything else about the place and location more than makes up for it

I was debating between this property and the excellent Royal Shiodome. Decided to give Solaria Nishitetsu a try.Location is indeed very convenient to Ginza if thats what you are looking for. But the rooms are tiny and not very efficiently laid out. I have stayed in small hotels such as Richmond and Daiwa Roynet with better space planning.I do appreciate them fulfilling our request of 2 rooms next to each other.Exit A8 of Higashi Ginza station after climbing around 30 steps.Will not return as there are more options.

Very new hotel, great architecture if a bit quirky. Reception staff struggle with English but are very helpful. Rooms small but very well equipped. Safe was difficult to find, great. Breakfast OK. Would recommend as for us the price was great.

Excellent hotel located right in the heart of Ginza. Within short walking distance to Tsukiji Fish Market, Yurakucho and Ginza shopping area. Just a few minutes' walk from Ginza subway station. Rooms were modern, comfy and spacious. Shower/bath area is huge. All in, an excellent hotel for the price and location. Highly recommended.

First time in Tokyo and traveling solo. The room was decent with nice amenities (I'd say even better shower gel and shampoo than the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo), very good location...only 10 minutes walk to Tsukiji Market, and 10 minutes walk (another direction) to the busy Ginza district. Hotel staff were nice, special thanks to Sakai-san (may have remembered incorrectly) who was particularly helpful in telling me where to go in Tsukiji Market and Ginza. Gone out on a Sunday night at 10:30 looking for a place for dinner, was walking alone on couple of blocks around the hotel, and felt very safe.

The hotel is conviniently located in Ginza. But the advantages finish here. The double beds in the room are very small. It is unacceptable that the staff hardly speaks english although the hotel is in a very posh neighbourhood. Rooms are small.

the hotel is spotless and quite spacious by japanese standards. very close to all the great shopping expensive stores as well as the metro stops.taxis are trustworhthy unlike some countries we have visited like jerusalem. baggage storage is available helpful staff and the tax ratei to tokyo station to catch the bullet train is about 750 yen. everything in ginza is expensive but for the ippedu noodle place round the corner of the hotel which has the best ramen .

Hotel is easily accessible from Higashi Ginza station, just less than 5 minutes' walk from either Exit A2 or A8 of the station. Depending on timing and train lines, one can easily take the train from Narita & Haneda Airports to Higashi Ginza station. From there the hotel is just a short walk away. Besides Higashi Ginza station, other stations e.g. Ginza station, Yurakucho station are also within walking distance although slightly further away. The hotel is strategically located in the upmarket district of Ginza surrounded by nice restaurants, departmental stores and retail shops. One can also walk to Tsukiji fish market in less than15 minutes.Rooms are small like most hotel rooms in Tokyo but modern & clean. Hotel staff are friendly any helpful too. We enjoyed our stay there.

We chose this boutique hotel for a week in Tokyo prior to joining a group tour based on location and reviews on this website. It didn't disappoint! The staff were very friendly and helpful when we required directions, restaurant reservations, luggage storage, taxi. The breakfast room staff were also excellent as was the food offered at the simple buffet. The only negative for us was the size of the double room. The bed was against the wall and there was very little room for luggage so we were forever moving our cases to access the fridge/bathroom/bed. The room was spotless and if ever back in Tokyo we would stay here again.

Clean room, bed slept well and breakfast was outstanding. Easy accessible location from two metro line stops. In the center of Ginza shopping. Some have complained about room being small, but I found it to have a lot of ingenious space saving technology. And the bathroom was bigger than many with perhaps the best steam shower I have been in, and in my hotel room no less. I would stay here again.

This hotel is great in terms of location. Near the Ginza and Hibiya line which easily took us to spots we like Omotesando and Daikanyama. It is also an easy walk to Tokyo Station for trips on other major attractions. All the major shopping centres are easy walking distance. There lots of dining options around for all budget. The breakfast bar have good food to kickstart a day. It is not a big selection but satisfying enough.The room we had was on the small side but it is expected for a Japanese standard hotel. The fridge didn't work at all. However, since we were out most of the days it was not a big issue.Bathroom amenities were all really good. The hotel smells so good as well all the time.Staff were helpful and friend.

This was a very nice room in a quiet location just steps away from the action. It was a great base for our first few days in Tokyo. The room was small, but luxurious. We walked to the Tsukiji Fish Market, the famous department stores in Ginza, and were easily able to hop on public transportation to see more. Highly recommend.

We stayed in 2014, I could not fault the service at all. Everyone was so kind.the rooms were comfortable and the lobby was very welcoming. We wanted to send our luggage to Osaka and could not find the place, the gentleman at the reception walked us down and translated for us. He really went out of his way to help and it just made our stay here perfect. If we return to Tokyo, this hotel will be where we will book!

The location of this hotel is unbeatable and centrally located in Ginza. 2 minute walk from A12 exit of the Ginza line (matsuya department store exit but close after 10pm at nite). If you arrive Tokyo through the Haneda airport, you can reach the Higashi Ginza station (Keikyu line --> Asakusa line). However, remember to check the direct train timetable and also get out from A1 exit (with elevator) if u get a big luggage and u just need to cross the road. When u head to the airport, just go to the Exit 3 (again with elevator)We arrived on the first nite at around 11pm from Haneda, the manager came out and told us the non-smoking premier twin room we booked (confirmed on the internet) were not available and offered us the smoking room at a discount (40000 yen discount for 4 nite stay pretty good deal). Else they offered us the non-smoking standard twin room also at a discount. In the end we took the smoking room. Although we were glad we got a discounted price with the same size of room, this kind of over booking is hard to understand as the room availability should be accurately monitored over the internet. I seldom encountered such cases in any other hotels in the world, not to mention about Japan. Anyway...The room was smaller than expected as the room size is said to be 34 sq. m. The bathroom was out of proportion large with a nice built in TV screen in the bath area (well personally i prefer the screen to be in the toilet section as one can hardly hear the TV when taking a shower) The make up area has two washing basins which is really a luxury. In-room amenities are also good with high quality. I especially like their shampoo and shower gel.The beds are relatively big by Tokyo twin room standard, both pillows and blankets are comfortable. However, with this room size, one can still hardly find space to put the luggages for two persons as some space is also wasted for the big door entrance area. Another minus is the lighting. Very dim indeed and also very hard to understand the switches for which one is for which. In house wifi is a bit on the slow side but acceptable.At night, sometimes you can hear some noise from the street (sirens or something) but this is kind of expected as it's in central Ginza. The restaurant inside the hotel seems very nice but we never tried. Reception area is small but staff in general helpful. There is also a courier service offered. However the hotel does NOT offer service to book restaurants in advance as they do not have a dedicate concierge service.We stayed in this hotel twice in this trip and the second time of stay we chose the standard twin room. Size is not a big difference except the bathroom is much much smaller. I would choose the premier though if you get a good deal as the standard room is really very small but normal in tokyo standard especially for central Ginza.

Very nice rooms which were well appointed and plenty big enough. Helpful staff. Tried lunch in the restaurant a couple of times which was really nice. Great location in the middle of Ginza with enough restaurants to stock a ship. You can eat really cheaply on delicious Rahman and tempura or go upmarket. A shoppers paradise. Easy walk to Tokyo station or the imperial palace

We only stayed there for a night in March. It is located in a very central location, short walk to the Higashi-Ginza station (where you can take a direct train from/to Haneda Airport), Ginza and surrounding areas. Not a lot of eating choices nearby, but Yurakucho just minutes away on foot. Room is small but very clean, comfortable bed. Expect busy concierge. Overall a very nice stay, would love to stay again.

Very good location just a block from the main Ginza street. Close to shopping center and subway station. Short walk to the fish market. Modern decor. Generous room size for Tokyo. Comfortable bed. Excellent bath tub and fragrance spa kits. Clean, quiet and relaxing. Recommended!
user_name:
SunnySideUpZ
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The hotel is an oasis. Each time I stepped off the elevator onto our floor I felt the subdued peacefulness from the décor and lighting. The room - a double was small with one side of the bed against the wall. The décor and layout made up for the smallness with a desk, and small sitting area. Large window with light blocking drapes. Bathroom was large as noted by others with a tub. There is also a small refrigerator. Excellent room wi-fi. We took a taxi from Tokyo Station Yen 850. Did not want to move through the Metro with luggage. There are two Metro stations - Ginza on the Ginza line (orange) Exit A12 and Higoshi-Ginza (red) Asakusa. The Asakusa line is the one from either Narita or Haneda. One exit for this line is by the Family Mart and the other is behind the Solaris near the Mitsui Garden Hotel. The coffee shop katty korner towards the Ginza station serves an interesting breakfast. There are several small restaurants on the side streets. A quiet pleasant area and a very Zen experience.

I stayed here twice for business and every time I stayed more than 7 nights. Before my arrival I have emailed them that if they have a room available for me then please let me check in earlier. However there was no answer and when I checked in it seemed nobody know about this and only allowed me in my room by 4 pm. The room is not cleaned properly, the telephone and television full of dusts. They do not tidy up your things but let them as they were. I am still staying there and see if it is improved or not. My flight is late and I asked them to grant a late check out for me as I said I stayed here long and please have some favor for long staying guests but the manager's answer is NO, if I want I have to pay. Maybe it is right as Tokyo may be busy and if I dont stay here they still have many other guests.

This hotel is in a great location right in the heart of Ginza. Starbucks is right around the corner, and shopping is just a stone's throw away.
